w:r.w:t: This document details the requirements for Feature E3, the
AI Career Fit & Simulation Engine + Skill Roadmap Generator
for the ShikshaCare platform. This feature is a core differentiator, moving beyond static job recommendations to provide highly personalized, data-driven career guidance.

The system will leverage the Student Digital Twin and advanced LLMs (Gemini, OpenAI) to simulate potential career paths, calculate readiness, predict stress load, and ultimately generate a structured, dependency-aware skill development roadmap towards a user-selected primary career goal.
Analyzes Digital Twin against Career KB
Decomposes career goal into learning stages
Feature E3 is critical for ShikshaCare's value proposition as a comprehensive EdTech and HealthTech platform.
Positions ShikshaCare as a predictive, outcome-focused platform rather than a generic learning tool.
A clear, achievable career roadmap increases user engagement and long-term retention.
ensures career goals are holistically healthy and sustainable for the user.
Demonstrates sophisticated, multi-model AI architecture (Gemini + OpenAI + MongoDB Context).

Traditional career guidance is often static, non-personalized, and fails to account for crucial personal factors like stress tolerance and learning speed. Students are often guided toward "popular" careers without understanding the readiness gap, required commitment, or the psychological load of the profession.
"I don't know which career path fits my unique profile (strengths, weaknesses, interests, and stress level), or exactly what I need to learn to get there."
A quantitative simulation that provides personalized metrics (Readiness %, Stress Load, Time-to-Ready) and an actionable, dependency-aware learning roadmap.
High relevance and accuracy of suggested careers
80% user rating (4/5 stars) on 'Career Relevance' survey question
User commitment to the generated roadmap
> 65% of users complete the first Skill Block of their roadmap within 30 days
90% of selected careers have a Predicted Stress Load score within the user's Stress Tolerance band
College student, high enthusiasm, uncertain about specific career, variable stress tolerance.
Needs clear, simulated paths and an estimate of the time commitment needed.
Working professional, clear time availability constraints, high burnout risk concern.
Needs a low-stress path and a roadmap that respects his limited time and learning pace.
User completes all required information (interests, strengths, stress tolerance, etc.) at signup.
User navigates to the "Career Fit" section.
The backend executes the multi-model AI logic.
System displays a loading screen: "Analyzing your Digital Twin... Simulating career paths..."
User is presented with 3-5 simulated careers.
Each option displays: Career Name, Readiness %, Predicted Stress Load (vs. Tolerance), Estimated Time-to-Ready.
UX Requirement: Must include clear reasoning from the AI for each metric.
User reviews options and selects ONE primary career goal.
System confirms selection and automatically generates the detailed learning roadmap.
UX Requirement: Confirmation modal: "Are you sure? This will lock your primary goal. You can only have one active goal at a time."
The generated roadmap (Career → Skill Blocks → Topics) is displayed on the user's main dashboard.
The following describes the flow starting
Frontend sends a request (user_id) to the
normalizes data and builds the structured AI prompt (as defined in Section 8).
The JSON response from Gemini is strictly validated against the contract (Section 9). If validation fails, trigger Fallback API Logic (Section 17).
Simulated careers are cross-referenced with the internal
for Market Demand data and real-world project complexity data.
Simulation data is returned to the user.
with the selected career ID and Digital Twin.
uses the Career KB to map dependencies (Skill Block A must precede Skill Block B) and generates the roadmap based on the user's learning speed and time availability.
The generated roadmap is stored in
The strategy emphasizes structure, context injection, and role-playing to achieve deterministic and high-quality results.
"You are a senior AI career guidance counselor and architect for an EdTech platform. Your goal is to provide
career simulations. Output MUST be in the requested Strict JSON format."
Defines role, goal, and output constraint.
Inject the full Student Digital Twin data (Interests, Strengths, Weaknesses, Stress Tolerance, Time Availability, Learning Speed, Education History).
Inject 5-7 top-level career categories from the Career KB related to user interests.
Grounds the AI in existing, validated roles (No Hallucination).

"Analyze the CONTEXT against the KNOWLEDGE BASE. Return 3-5 distinct career paths. For each path, calculate: 1. Readiness % (based on Skill Gaps). 2. Predicted Stress Load (1-10, correlate to tolerance). 3. Estimated Time-to-Ready (weeks/months). 4. Detailed Reasoning. Return STRICT JSON."
Defines the required output and metrics.
The API contract ensures determinism and consistency between the primary and fallback models.
MongoDB acts as the authoritative memory for all simulation and roadmap states.
Stores the results of every simulation run.
Snapshot of the Digital Twin used
The 3-5 simulation results (mirrors the JSON schema)
Stores the user's one active career goal.
Snapshot of Readiness %, Stress Load, etc. at selection
True if required for a later stage
Compares the user's known skills/strengths (from Digital Twin) against the essential skills required for the career (from Career KB).
Essential, high-impact skills have a higher weight ($\text{Weight}_i$) in the calculation.
that contribute most to the low readiness score and provides them in the reasoning.
(1-10) for each job role (e.g., Investment Banker: 9, Librarian: 3).
If a user has "Weakness: Poor time management" and "Career: Project Manager," the Baseline Stress Score is adjusted
Market demand data is pre-computed and stored in the Career KB (updated quarterly).
(1-10) from the KB for the suggested career.

The AI must provide reasoning linking the retrieved score to the career's long-term viability (e.g., "Market Demand is high due to rapid adoption of cloud infrastructure, aligning with the necessary AWS skills").
The roadmap must be dependency-aware and personalized for pace.
The selected career (from Career KB) is broken down into mandatory
Determine prerequisites (e.g., "Databases" must precede "Advanced SQL"). This is a pre-defined graph structure in the Career KB.
The roadmap prioritizes Skill Blocks that directly address the user's initial
The total estimated time-to-ready is distributed across the Skill Blocks, factoring in the user's
from the Digital Twin to estimate time per block.
Final output is Career → Skill Blocks → Topics, ensuring a clear learning path.
The Career Knowledge Base (KB) is the non-AI, authoritative source for career structure and data.
System blocks simulation. Prompts user to complete the profile: "Please detail your past projects to enable simulation."
Interests (e.g., art) conflict with Strengths (e.g., math) and Weaknesses (e.g., poor attention to detail).
careers that blend signals (e.g., "Data Visualization Artist"). The reasoning must explicitly call out the conflict and how the career resolves it.
Digital Twin shows high burnout risk despite high stress tolerance.
, even if the user is technically ready for higher-stress roles. Must include a warning in the reasoning.
All simulation metrics (Readiness %, Stress Load) must be accompanied by explicit, non-vague reasoning (Section 9.2).
The KB data and AI prompts must exclude protected characteristics (e.g., age, gender, race) to prevent bias in recommendations.
The user has the final authority to select a career, regardless of the AI's recommendation. The AI provides
Ensure the Digital Twin normalization process filters out demographic markers not relevant to skill or capability.
The Career KB must be periodically audited to ensure career roles are not implicitly biased towards certain groups (e.g., ensuring "Software Engineer" skills are not gendered).
The SYSTEM prompt explicitly instructs the AI to prioritize
The system must maintain high availability using a multi-model approach.
If the Gemini API request fails (HTTP 5xx, timeout > 5s, or JSON schema validation fails).
immediately formats the exact same prompt (Section 8) and sends it to the
The response from OpenAI is processed and normalized to strictly adhere to the defined JSON response schema (Section 9.2).
The fallback usage must be logged for subsequent failure analysis. If both fail, trigger Failure Recovery (Section 18).
If the entire simulation fails (both Gemini and OpenAI fail, or database connection is lost):
Display a user-friendly error message: "Our AI systems are currently updating. Please try again in 5 minutes." Do not expose internal technical details.
) via PagerDuty. Log the full request, input Digital Twin, and the failure type to a persistent logging service.
Career KB update process must be documented and repeatable
The Digital Twin can only be accessed by the
Only the necessary Digital Twin context is sent to the external LLM APIs (no PII like names or email addresses).
Sensitive data (e.g., specific stress scores) should be masked in logs where possible.
Roadmap modification is locked unless an explicit admin reset is performed, protecting the integrity of the user's goal.
The Minimum Viable Product (MVP) must achieve the core loop:
Simulation: 3 career paths with 4 mandatory metrics (Readiness, Stress, Time-to-Ready, Gaps).
Selection: Locking the primary career goal (one active goal).
Roadmap: Generation of one-level deep structure (Career → Skill Blocks).
Architecture: Fully implemented Gemini + MongoDB + Fallback API Logic.
Knowledge Base: Initial release based on a minimum of 50 validated career roles.
Monetization or payment integration for career guidance.
Integration of the roadmap into the core learning curriculum/content delivery platform (this will be Feature E4).
Real-time monitoring of user stress based on external inputs (e.g., Apple Watch data).
Multi-goal tracking (only one active goal is allowed).
Social sharing or collaboration features for roadmaps.
System suggests non-existent or irrelevant careers.
(AI only suggests careers present in the KB).
System promotes traditionally biased career choices.
against known bias vectors; continuous monitoring.
Adjusting the roadmap in real-time based on user activity, performance, and skill assessments.
Estimating potential income trajectory and required educational cost.
Integrating real-world project difficulty scores from the KB into the Time-to-Ready estimate.
Recommending mentors based on the user's selected career and identified skill gaps.
